Can-do statement: Can use the possessive pronoun 'ours', in subject position.

I hope that other councils will consider improving the cyclists' cycling conditions as ours did. (Skills for Life; L2; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Arabic - Other; Fail)

Yes, of course there are much larger gardens in this area, but ours is more than four times as big as the one we had in Holland. (Netherlands; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Dutch; Pass)

What is more, the manager organises excursions to London. Ours was breathtaking. We visited unbelievably interesting museums? (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'that of' and 'those of' as a possessive form, in formal and professional contexts.
Example:
It is widely known that the Russian educational system differs dramatically from that of the European, Asian or American countries. (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Russian; Pass) 

The strength of our product is that it fits the customers' demands - especially those of middle-aged single consumers. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; German; Pass)

Therefore, I urge you to publish this letter and reconsider your opinions, which clearly do not reflect those of the general population. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2001; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use pronouns 'none' to substitute for subject and object pronouns. ►  pronouns: substitution
Example:
As for disadvantages, in fact, I see none. (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Russian; Pass)

As for social life organized by the school, there was none . (France; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; French; Pass)

The costs saved without external consultants would be higher than the costs for this course . Opportunity costs: None. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; German; Pass)

I started learning the language when I was seven. Problems when using English? None. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can modify 'few' and 'many' with 'very', 'too', 'so' as intensifiers.
Example:
It was on Thursday that I realized how many children were in the centre. There were too many and the day was extremely tiring. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Almost 5000 Greeks died that night, and very few managed to survive. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Greek; Pass)

In recent years, the Internet, which used to be a luxury only used by the very few who had access to it, has become a means of exchanging information. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Sure, some of the motorists changed to bicycles or to public transport - but far too few. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'some of', 'many of' to modify relative pronouns in a relative clause.
Example:
The people of his time were amazed every time they saw his new inventions, some of which were enormous. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Greek; Pass)

By and large, how we eat is influenced by several factors, some of which have nothing to do with your nationality. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Spanish - European; Pass)

I am aware that you have a different view on young people's preferences, but I hope this event could give you an opportunity to see some other aspects of young people, some of whom are very active in sports in our club. (Korea, South; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1999; Korean; Pass)

Today we continue this tradition by organising lectures and exhibitions, generally open to the public, many of which deal with Hamburg-specific issues. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2006; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'none' as a pronoun. ►  determiners: quantity  ►  pronouns: quantity
Example:
Then I searched for a Coca-Cola, but I found none. (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Greek; Pass)

Although I was really disappointed, I managed to keep the presence of mind and think more carefully and calmly. The result? None! (Greece; B2 VANTAGE; 1993; Greek; Pass)

We expected a social programme but there was none. (France; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; French; Fail)

The odd thing about snowboarding in Russia ... is that there are very few mountains. In fact, there are none. (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Russian; Pass)

The costs saved without external consultants would be higher than the costs for this course. Opportunity costs: None. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'each' (+ noun or pronoun) as subject followed by 'the other(s)' a complement of a preposition, to refer to two related things. ► pronouns: quantity
Example:
Each person could be a help to the other. (Sri Lanka; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Tamil; Pass)

They all seem to mean exactly the same but if you study them more carefully, you realize that each of them differs from the others in tiny details that can be relevant. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Generally speaking, each individual is different from the others. (Vietnam; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2011; Urdu;)

Can-do statement: Can use affirmative and negative forms of question tags with 'there' + 'be'.
Example:
As you put it that way, there isn't much of a difference with our time, is there? (Netherlands; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Dutch; Pass)

But there is always something you can improve, isn't there? (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use verb + particle + preposition, where the preposition is separated from its complement. ► Prepositions
Example:
Anyway, let me tell you what ideas I came up with. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

Sometimes in order to feel confident and to be inspired we need a person to look up to. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

This you will have to look out for. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Swedish; Pass)

This shows her superficiality, which Kingshaw cannot put up with. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Firstly, let me express that the situation you describe is certainly not something my client could easily put up with. (Czech Republic; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2008; Czech; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a wide range of phrasal verbs + object pronoun + particle.
Example:
[talking about a band] I went to check them out last week and here is my review of the two concerts. (Denmark; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; Danish; Pass)

[talking about a living room] I tried to clean it up as much as possible. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Swedish; Pass)

[talking about setting up an office phone system] We just need a small set and a little time to fix it up. (China; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2002; Chinese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form ellipted 'if' clauses with 'if' + '-ed' form.
Example:
Furthermore I found little rooms where an employee could take a short nap if needed. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2002; Swiss German; Pass)

Meals are served, if requested, three times a day, unless picnic lunches are needed. (Switzerland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; German; Pass)

Women who want to start a career more often decide to be single or, if married, don't devote much time to the family. (Poland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can introduce a conditional subordinate clause with 'should' + inverted subject.
Example:
Should you require any further information about the program or any other detail please do not hesitate to ask for it. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2002; Spanish - European; Pass)

Should there be a lack of mutual understanding a break-up is unavoidable. (C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use negative pronoun 'none' to substitute for subject and object pronouns or noun phrases. ► pronouns: substitution
Example:
In fact, there are none, but the hills that do exist can be dubbed mountains - just because there are none... (Russia; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2005; Russian; Pass)

Concerning your question about any special requirements of some students - I am glad that I am able to tell you that there are none this year. (Germany; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1998; German; Pass)

Problems when using English? None. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1993; Spanish - European; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'not with indefinite pronouns 'everyone' and 'everything' and determiners 'every', 'all'.
Example:
Not everyone likes sports or music. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Not everything was as good as we expected. (Poland; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Polish; Pass)

Not all students, though, can attend the centre as it is not always open, and their lessons finish at 5 pm, the closing time of the centre. (Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Greek; Pass)

Not all of us have got the fighting spirit to visit the gym regularly, but many of us would like to have a healthy look. (Sweden; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 1999; Swedish; Pass)

Not every cyclist is a danger to the public as most of them obey all rules and respect other road users. (C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2007; Slovak; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can combine more complex, lengthy strings of adjectives, joining the last two adjectives with 'and'.
Example:
A timid, shy, self-conscious, over-sensitive and vulnerable person can yearn to make friends with someone who is very self-assured, confident, decisive, even bossy. (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Polish; Pass)

In the increasingly materialistic, greedy and shallow society we live in today, it would almost seem that there are no disadvantages to being rich. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use adjectives in 'as … as' and 'so … that' in comparative structures. ► comparative clauses
Example:
Because our debates do not draw as large a number of students as the guest appearances, but are still enjoyed by a relevant number of students, we propose a change of focus for the events. (Sweden; C2 MASTERY; 2006; Swedish; Pass)

It was such a riddle that I went and saw my psycho-analyst, who revealed to me that I once had so strong a shock that I was now walking and hiding my money in my sleep. (France; C2 MASTERY; 1998; French; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form adverb phrases with modifiers before, and complements after, adverbs.
Example:
Many politicians and owners of big enterprises have been able for a long time to work almost exclusively for their own interests. (C2 MASTERY; 1993; ; Pass)

It was so completely in harmony with the sun, the sea, the sand, the summer, I decided instantly that was the kind of thing I would like to keep and collect. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2002; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'as if' + non-finite clause to introduce a second clause as a comparison.
Example:
She closed her eyes as if to push those thoughts away. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

There it was: the chef's body, hacked to pieces, a carving knife in his hand as if to scare off an enemy. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Portuguese; Pass)

I was so frightened that my heart was beating like crazy as if trying to leave my body. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Because of this, my mother never denied us anything, as if trying to compensate for our father's death. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How' + clause.
Example:
How I often longed to play with the other children or relax with a good book. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

How I love the smell of home! (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

How I long to be there again. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Dutch; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'How' + adverb + clause.
Example: How differently we were brought up by our mother. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: SINGULAR NOUN ENDING IN 'S' + APOSTROPHE
Can-do statement: Can use an apostrophe after singular nouns ending in 's', to indicate possession.
Example: However, I believe that in order to maintain its popularity, the programme should keep some of the series' aspects the same, but alter some others. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use ''s' without a following noun when the noun has already been mentioned or is obvious in the context.
Example:
Olivia's experiences probably are the narrator's. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

He started to shake me and meanwhile I heard a familiar voice; it was my father's. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Suddenly, after two weeks I realised that my bank account was empty and so was my friend's. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Dutch; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use two possessive ''s' constructions in the same noun phrase.
Example:
There were no photographs of him in Ann 's mother's albums. (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Polish; Pass)

They spent two weeks together at Emily's grandmother's house, after fourteen months of dating. (Argentina; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form of the future perfect simple.
Example: Will he have changed? (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Catalan; Fail)

Can-do statement: Can use 'be' + 'going to' with a wide range of adverbs before the main verb.
Example:
But I don't know if I'm going to still live here. (Uruguay; B1 THRESHOLD; 2007; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

First, I am going to briefly introduce the three main activities offered by the club. (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 2006; French; Pass)

Nobody is going to even look at you when your sister is there. (Israel; C2 MASTERY; 1997; Russian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the present simple with 'only when' (followed by 'will' and inverted subject) to refer to the future.
Example:
Only when we understand that, will we be able to live in better societies. (Argentina; C2 MASTERY; 2005; Spanish - Latin American; Pass) 

Moreover, I think that only when people manage this will they be able to move on with their lives and offer something new to humanity. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

And, sadly, I also believe that only when something really catastrophic happens will citizens face reality and accept that measures must be taken. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 2010; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'be' + 'not' + adjective + 'to' + infinitive.
Example:
The country's population is not likely to increase fast enough. (France; C2 MASTERY; 1993; French; Pass)

[talking about relatives] You are not obliged to invite them over. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Greek; Pass)

[talking about tourism] Its positive effects are not certain to outweigh the negative ones. (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'have to have' + '-ed'.
Example:
[talking about urban versus rural life] In order to have an objective view on which lifestyle tends to be more problematic, you certainly have to have lived at each setting for a rather extensive time period. (Greek, C2 MASTERY, Pass, 2001)

They stop at the most famous places, which you "have to have seen", jump down and take photographs, always chatting with each other. (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'might as well', mostly to talk about or suggest what we think is the easiest or most logical course of action, often when we cannot see a better alternative. ► 'may'
Example:
Living longer allows you to fulfil the different stages of your personal development, and if you reach the necessary maturity and integrity that corresponds to this stage of your life, you might as well make the best of these years. (Catalan, C2 MASTERY, Pass, 1993)

What should be changed about travelling and spending one's holiday is that the people, in my opinion, should decide on what they want to do during their holidays: If they only want to have fun, they might as well stay at home. (Germany; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use ellipted 'must have' + '-ed' without a subject. ► ellipsis
Example: [from a story] 'Must have fallen out of a car, or somfin'" This was his next thought. (Polish, C2 MASTERY)

Can-do statement: Can invert 'must' and the subject after negative phrases, e.g. 'not only', 'never', 'nor', to change the focus and give prominence/emphasis.
Example:
Not only must you study really hard during university, but also keep studying afterwards. (Portuguese, C2 MASTERY)

To sum up, my opinion is that education is sacred, necessary and useful to all of us and never must it be characterised as "a waste of time". (Greek, C2 MASTERY)

[talking about personality] Nor must we overlook the human qualities. (French, C2 MASTERY)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must not have been' (especially with 'easy').
Example:
But I would like to stress that I was really happy that she found another husband, although she had three little children which must not have been easy for him. (German, C2 MASTERY)

Something I have missed on behalf of my father is a bit more tenderness, but again I am guessing it must not have been easy for him to be a post-wartime son of a widow. (Spanish - European, C2 MASTERY)

It mustn't have been more than an hour after the first announcement of the captain that there was a second one. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'must' with a wide range of adverbs in the normal mid position after the modal verb. ► adverbs|
Example:
There must certainly be other solutions to the problem of the need for space for new houses. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

RECOMMENDATION In my opinion our town must clearly use this area to create a park and a playground for children. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

I must completely disagree with this statement, since I believe that in all jobs or occupations only the good professionals are able to earn a lot of money. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 2005; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
Need you ask? (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2002; Greek; Pass)

Lastly I would appreciate , as I am sure others would too, if the premises were cleaner. Need I say more? (India; 2005; English;)

Can-do statement: Can use 'oughtn't' (without 'to') + verb.
Example: …they will most certainly have a banquet that day... and you oughtn't miss it for the world! (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the negative form 'ought not to'.
Example:
Secondly, there ought not to be a division between rich and poor. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1999; Dutch; Pass)

We ought not to forget that in the last twenty years the food industry has increased the number of chemicals used in its products. (Uruguay; C2 MASTERY; 2006; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'ought' + subject + 'not to' + verb to form (rhetorical) questions, often in formal contexts.
Example: And if not, ought we not to learn from the mistakes of the past? (Denmark; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Danish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use negative form 'used not to'
Example:
I used to play until late in the evening, I used not to do my homework and I did not excel at school. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

As a teenager I used not to be very sociable, I had few friends and none of them felt close. (Poland; C2 MASTERY; 2003; Polish; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use a wide range of adverbs with 'would', including 'undoubtedly', 'possibly', 'normally', 'personally', 'eventually', 'obviously', 'significantly', 'inevitably'. ► adverbs
Example:
[talking about the construction of a leisure centre] I believe that the construction of such a centre would undoubtedly contribute to the improvement of our quality of life. (Greek, C2 MASTERY, Pass, 2009)

Organising family-oriented activities would significantly increase membership and raise the society's popularity with the local community. (Greek, C2 MASTERY, Pass, 2009)

Guideword: FORM: COMPLEX NOUN PHRASES WITH 'LITTLE OR NO'  + NOUN
Can-do statement: Can form complex noun phrases with 'little or no' + noun.
Example:
Harvey Keitel has always chosen the scripts that interested him as a person and as an actor, whilst refusing to invest his talent in big-time Hollywood block-busters with little or no artistic value. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

They have little or no spare time to relax and recharge their batteries; they are constantly under pressure in order to live up to the expectations of the team and the supporters. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

The careers of these people started at a very young age with little or no money. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use non-finite '-ing' perfect forms of the passive as the complement of prepositions.
Example:
They are expected to give the couple expensive presents as a reward for having been invited. (C2 Spanish - Latin American)

We caught the bus as if we were escaping from Saigon, and with the sensation of having been rewarded with one of the funniest holiday evenings of our lives. (C2 Spanish - European)

Miss Kenton has just been employed as a housekeeper when she knocks on Stevens' pantry door and comes in without having been bidden to do so, bringing a vase of flowers. (C2 Italian)

Can-do statement: Can use the question form.
Example:
What had he been doing that morning? (France; C2 MASTERY; 1993; French; Pass)

So, why had she been waiting for so long a time? (France; C2 MASTERY; 1993; French; Fail)

Guideword: FORM: FIXED EXPRESSIONS 'HAD IT NOT BEEN FOR', 'IF IT HADN'T BEEN FOR'
Can-do statement: Can use 'had it not been for' and 'if it hadn't been for' with a modal form for giving reasons.
Example:
Had it not been for the fact that I had already read the article, I would have thought that this woman was at least thirty years old. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2001; Greek; Pass)

Another aspect of his emotional side is the fact that he is a very private person, and had it not been for this feature, he might have been able to react differently. (Denmark; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Danish; Pass)

If it hadn't been for my lack of knowledge, skills, experience, and some other things like that, I wouldn't have been fired. (Israel; C2 MASTERY; 1997; Russian; Pass)

They had become very good friends and their friendship could have gone a little further if it hadn't been for Dan's character. (Argentina; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Spanish - Latin American; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can invert the subject and affirmative auxiliary verb with 'hardly ... when' to talk about something that happened immediately before something else, in formal contexts.
Example:
Hardly had she spoken these words when it dawned on the musician that life could not continue like that. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Spanish - European; Pass)

Hardly had he taken them from the counter when the monster vanished again. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the possessive pronoun 'hers' with singular reference, in subject position.
Example:
I put Sophie's pictures in my bag because hers was already packed. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)


[talking about gazpacho, a type of soup] I also recall my father saying to my mother that hers was not as good as my grandmother's. (Spain; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2003; Spanish - European; Pass)

She thought, as she sometimes did, that hers was a drab existence, but that she could do hardly anything to avoid it. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Catalan; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the possessive pronoun 'his', with singular and plural reference, in subject and object position, and complement positions after 'be' and after prepositions.
Example:
Therefore, his was not a happy and normal childhood. (C2 MASTERY; 1993; Spanish - Other; Fail)

He was my confidant and I was his. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

It was as if she had completely forgotten about the outlines of his face, his hair, all the features that were his. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish ? Latin American)

Bob attracts many of his students to the teaching career, which is rather looked down on in a developing poor country like his. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use the possessive pronouns 'hers', 'theirs' and 'his' after noun + 'of'.
Example:
I was a great admirer of hers. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

She asked some old friends of hers and she went to the church where the marriage was taking place. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Greek; Fail)

My parents invited the father of a friend of theirs who spoke French. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian)

Then he showed me a very old diary of his, just for me to have an idea of what to do. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese)

He was able to build a very successful business which allowed him and his family to live very well and to travel (a passion of his). ( Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish ? Latin American)

Can-do statement: Can use the possessive pronoun 'theirs', with singular and plural reference, in subject position.
Example:
Theirs is a relationship between two members of the privileged classes, who really don't care about the world around (or below) them. (Portugal; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Theirs had always been a love-and-hate relationship. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

Yet, beautiful dreams never last long, and theirs lasted until she had to leave England. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian)

When comparing the value and achievements of athletes with doctors or scientists, theirs begin to lack in significance. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form a cleft construction beginning with 'it' to emphasise the subject of the main clause. ► clauses
Example: It was my father who took all this away from me. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

Can-do statement: Can use 'a lot' and 'much' as a subject pronouns. ► focus
Example:
A lot has changed since prehistoric times. (Netherlands; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Dutch; Pass)

A lot depends on your background. (Romania; C2 MASTERY; 2007; Romanian; Pass)

Much has been said about the need for nuclear weapons, although after the end of USSR and consequently the end of the cold war, this topic was almost forgotten. (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1998; Portuguese; Pass)

Much has been said about quality time, but children don't understand this concept, they only know whether you are there or you are not. (Spain; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can use 'each' (+ noun or pronoun) as subject followed by 'the other(s)' as object , to refer to two related things. ► pronouns: quantity
Example:
Each of them admires the other's intelligence. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

As regards other aspects of my upbringing my parents taught me the importance of having all the family together, each one helping the others, each one loving the others. (Italy; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Italian; Pass)

Can-do statement: Can form alternative questions with two or more clauses and ellipsis in the second or third clause.
Example:
Is it not better to take the television away or stop them going to the cinema? (Switzerland; C2 MASTERY; 1993; German; Pass)

Do you enjoy reading, find it a waste of time or have an indifferent attitude to it? (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2008; Greek; Pass)

Is he going to give it back to me or show it to everybody? (Brazil; C2 MASTERY; 1993; Portuguese; Pass)

Guideword: FORM: VERB + DIRECT OBJECT + PARTICLE + PREPOSITION + OBJECT
Can-do statement: Can use a direct object with some prepositional verbs as well as an object of the preposition.
Example: It is widely accepted that being a loyal and trusted individual means that the people around us can trust us or let us in on a secret. (Greece; C2 MASTERY; 2009; Greek; Pass)
